comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: The first Government run Baby Clinic was opened in Alexandria on 24 August 1914: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3293685257/]This one followed shortly afterwards. The history of the clinics can be found here - 'Beginnings of Organised Baby Health Clinics' in Our babies: the state's best asset - A history of 75 years of baby health services in New South Wales (Sydney : Media and Communications, NSW Health, 21 August 2003), p. 24 An interior shot of the Newtown Baby Clinic: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2593233267/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Good work! My Googling and Troving produced an address at 22 Australia Street, Newtown. The street numbering has changed, but the terrace of houses is still there, across the street from Newtown Court House. I am not sure which one was the Baby Clinic - Google Street view - maps.google.com.au/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks for adding these links to the history of clinics.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Interesting to see how important gardens and hedges (and trees) have become over time. Although I can see tram lines above which is probably why there are no trees.

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] The lack of any vegetation in these old photos is a constant surprise to me.  It must have made the streets relatively hotter and windier, and would explain why the parks and gardens were so popular.  I tried to find if the tram went along Australia Street, Newtown - it didn't, so that black wire must have been telephone or power.
